Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Topics in Nonlinear Wave Equations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The nonlinear wave equations, that arise in specific problems in areas like general relativity, elasticity or field theory, are quite well understood from physical point of view. However, to claim a rigorous mathematical picture, there is still work to be done, and this is why solving problems connected to these equations could lead to new ideas and new interpretations in their area of origin. This project plans to investigate issues like local well-posedness, lifespan of low regularity solutions, and blowup phenomena. Also, the investigator will focus on similar problems for stochastic nonlinear wave equations. It is likely that recent advances for deterministic hyperbolic equations (e.g. vectorfield method, wave packet parametrices) could improve the current state of the art for these problems, which have applications in mathematical finance.

Problem solving is widely considered as one of the focal points in the instruction process of mathematics. The investigator will work on an educational plan integrated into the above research program, which has both an undergraduate component and a K-12 outreach one. The former includes the continuous development of the current Problem Solving Seminar, together with the creation of new courses both at undergraduate and graduate level, which will address the subject of partial differential equations. The K-12 component focuses on the creation of a Rochester Area Math Circle, aimed at middle-school and high-school students with an interest in solving challenging math problems. This activity will feature weekly lectures, problem sessions and math olympiads, in which a wide range of math educators and students will be involved.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to investigate the qualitative features for a set of challenging partial differential equations, which model physical phenomena appearing in connection to atomic physics and water waves. If the physical understanding of these problems is quite thorough by now, the research supported by this grant was aimed to contribute to their mathematical understanding, which was in its infancy.

For the Skyrme and Skyrme-like models of nuclear physics, outcomes of this research provide a detailed global dynamics theory for the case when one makes an extra natural geometric assumption. Specifically, in joint work with K. Nakanishi, S. Rajeev, D. da Silva, and X. Zhang, the PI proved non-concentration of energy and small data sharp global regularity results. These form the basis of ongoing investigations of similar issues for the general case of these problems. For the generalized Boussinesq equation modeling water waves, together with A. Himonas and D. Karapetyan, the PI showed that the associated flow map is not smooth if the initial data is not regular enough.

Another outcome of this project is an almost complete lecture notes volume, written in collaboration with M. Grillakis and entitled ``An introduction to the theory of wave maps and related problems."  It presents the most recent results for the wave maps system and its physically inspired generalizations in a format accessible to a wide audience including advanced graduate students. This book will be published by World Scientific.

Funds from this grant were used to provide research support for three graduate students, who wrote their dissertations having the PI as their doctoral advisor, as well as for travel support for the PI and his collaborators.   
A secondary goal of this project was to implement an educational plan for a large group of grades 6-12 and undergraduate students, with strong mathematical abilities, that emphasized learning and developing new problem solving skills. This led first to the successful creation by the PI of the Rochester Area Math Circle, an outreach math activity aimed at improving the mathematical background of gifted middle-school and high-school students and mentoring them towards promising careers. Secondly, through his Problem Solving Seminar, the PI trained undergraduate students interested in participating in mathematical contests, who later joined prestigious graduate programs.
